Hi All,

The 'how to test private methods' question (see below) came up on the NUnit
group, and I thought some TDD gurus here might be able to help out. Sorry if
this has already been rehashed a hundred times, but I was wrestling with
this a lot myself, and despite reading the Wiki threads on this, I still
don't have a good 'pattern' to use... 

The example from my case was a class, KeyAuthenticator, with a method
Validate(). Validate calls several internal methods to check hashcodes,
timestamps, etc. but the client shouldn't really need to know about any of
that. The problem was that the methods for checking hashcodes and timestamps
were the parts that needed the most testing...

public class KeyAuthenticator {
	//... instance variables etc...
	public bool Validate() {
		if (!CheckTimestamp()) return false;
		if (!CheckHash()) return false;
		return true;
	}

	private bool CheckTimestamp() {
		//... timestamp math
	}	
	
	private bool CheckHash() {
		//... MD5 hash comparison
	}

} 

Leaving out the backdoor reflection approach for the moment, the choices
seemed to be:

1) "pollute" the interface by making methods public that should be private.
Some argue that this is the correct thing to do, but generally accepted
principles of good design seem to require making your public interface as
minimal as possible.

2) Only test the public interface, perhaps giving up detailed testing of
internal logic.
The argument for this is that if the internal logic can't be easily tested
through exercising the public API, then you should theoretically be able to
get rid of all the 'untestable' code, since it can't ever be reached...
Somehow to me (as an admitted TDD newbie), it just seemed better to be able
to bang on these internal methods directly, rather than relying on the
public methods to access them. It seems easier and cleaner to test a method
in isolation than to try to test it only via it's caller... 

3) Make more classes... change the private methods into public methods of
new simple classes. 
To use the example above, I could create a 'KeyHash' class and a
'KeyTimestamp' class, then have each of these expose public methods...
perhaps this is the best refactoring, but it seemed to me to cause a
profusion of one-method classes...

4) Make the methods 'protected', have your Test class inherit from your
class under test.
This does work, however having a bunch of protected methods in your class
interface could give the impression to future users that the class was
designed to be inherited from, which is not really true in this case...

I'd love to hear the group's thoughts...

Thanks in advance,

Henry Stapp
